description: Sven Halek, after days of escalating chaos and debate within the Council, quietly authorizes the shutdown of BCI scoring. He drafts a concise statement to be released if questioned, emphasizing the need for the city to reclaim its future.
The BCI stops all scoring and restrictions without any official notice. Citizens gradually realize the system is gone; confusion and rumors spread as daily routines become unpredictable.
Critical city services and access points stall without the BCI; the Council is paralyzed, unable to restore order or direct policy. Citizens begin organizing local committees to fill the void.
Grassroots networks take shape across neighborhoods to coordinate aid, resolve disputes, and ensure basic needs are met. The first open forums on the future of city governance are held.
Amid vigorous public debate and rallies, the Council concedes to growing demands for democracy. Drafting begins on a new citizen-written charter, officially ending Stenograd’s algorithmic era.
